segments.text: So each time we turn the tape over, then we have that 15-second protective delay.
Now, first, Professor Fleming, I'd like to know what interested you in the sea.
Why did you choose the sea as a profession?
Well, I was studying as a chemist at the University of British Columbia and completed my bachelor's degree in 1929 and stayed on at the
the University of British Columbia, take a master's degree in chemistry.
And this, as you should recognize, was the beginning of the Depression.
And it was quite obvious to me that there were more chemists than were going to be needed, and that it was particularly difficult to obtain any sort of graduate degree.
student support in chemistry, and I had become somewhat bored with the field of chemistry and thought I'd better seek some other area.
And I'd grown up right by the water, and many of my friends were essentially marine biologists, and I happened to hear about this field called oceanography, and it seemed very intriguing.
So I was able to obtain a
research assistantship at Scripps Institution, Bahia, California, in 1931, down there.
Had you not been to Scripps before you acquired it?
No.
In those days, one didn't travel very much, and it was a major expedition to get to Southern California.
Actually, I went down by ship.
And did you know with whom you wished to work at Scripps when you went?
Not really.

I expected to work in chemistry, and at that time the chemist at Scripps was Eric Moberg, and I did essentially work with him for a number of years, although I moved out of the field of chemical oceanography after a few years.
game involved in sort of descriptive physical oceanography.
Now, how long were you at Scripps?
Well, I was there as a graduate student for four years, and I completed my Ph.D. in 1935, and then was kept on in sort of research capacity for one year just as an assistant, and then they

In 1936, I was appointed as an instructor on the faculty at Scripps, and this was at the time that Harold Fairgroup had just been appointed and came in as the director, which he did in September of 1936.
When did you first acquire the idea of the textbook that became the standard in the field?
more or less by accident, as a lot of these things do, that Scripps had never had any particular program in sort of education.
And when Harold Spherdrup came as the director, he felt that we ought to be doing more in this line, and he started some summer courses in

in oceanography, sort of a general survey course, and he and Martin Johnson and I were the principal lecturers, and the Prentice Hall Publishing Company apparently heard about this through their grapevine and came down and suggested that we write down our lecture notes, and being all innocent, we said yes, we would be willing to do so.
And it was out of this summer course in oceanography that the volume on the oceans finally appeared.
It took us about three years to write it, and it was finished in 1942.
What sort of work were you doing at Scripps while you were there?
Oh, I went down.
Do you mean as a graduate student?
As a graduate student and then always.
I was sort of Jack of all trades and have been, I think, all my career.
But my principal interest was originally in some sort of chemical work, and I did some work on the calcium carbonate problem, something on nutrients.
and used to participate in the very limited sort of seagoing program we had in those days.
And then in 1932, I was given a leave, in a sense, and went up to Berkeley, to the University of California,
to get a little bit more coursework and to prepare for my general examinations.

And when I came back to Scripps from there, early in 1933, I was told that the Navy wanted somebody to go down to Central America to carry out some oceanographic work on board one of the naval vessels.

I went down and joined the USS Hannibal, which was a vessel used by the then Navy Hydrographic Office, and spent several months down off the west coast of Panama and Costa Rica doing just sort of the field routine which had already been sort of planned.
And when I got back to
La Jolla, they said, well, why don't you write up the results?
And so this actually turned out to be my doctoral thesis and got me into sort of descriptive physical oceanography.
That was what I was interested in, is when did you get this first descriptive oceanography that you were in in the early 30s?
And you stayed with that, though, for two or three years.
I think of you more there than as a chemical oceanographer.
Oh, yes.
I haven't really done any chemical oceanography.

since that time, really, because as soon as I had finished up my thesis on this particular material, why, Dr. Sverdrup had arrived and was very anxious to start a more kind of systematic program of field work.

And this developed in a sort of indirect way, as many of these enterprises did, in that the California Fish and Game Commission was at that time concerned with the problem of the distribution and abundance of California sardines and wanted to do some oceanographic work.
made available to Scripps the use of a small patrol vessel called the Bluefin.
And in the early spring, and I think it extended up into the summer of 1937, we got our first systematic series of observations off the Southern California coast.
And this continued and so on, so we became very much involved in essentially the regional oceanography off the coast of California.
Who worked in the sardine fisheries activities with you?
Well, we just did a certain amount of work on conventional physical oceanography.
a little bit of chemistry and some work on the plankton.

We never became at that time directly involved in any of the fish studies, but the federal government had also become very much involved in the problem, and the two people that we dealt with a good deal were Alton B. Setty and Lionel Walford, both of
what was then, I think, the Bureau of Commercial Fisheries, although they changed their names often.
I'm not quite sure of this one.
But they were very much involved in the fisheries aspect and also the state fisheries.
And the man in the state fisheries with whom we work very closely now at USC is Richard B. Tibby.
run across, and he came down after a year or two and actually finished his PhD at Scripps on the oceanography of the California coast.
Now, this is really the first time the Pacific coast is being mapped, is when you're mapping it now in these several years.
Were you surprised about certain things?
Well, I think it's
Yes and no.
Because of the interest in the sardine problem, the region was more or less prescribed for us.
And yet within that area, which extended off the coast, I imagine about a couple of hundred miles,
They wanted considerable detail, so I think one of the things that was rather original was the fact that we made repeated studies on a fairly closely spaced network of stations.
This showed details that were essentially unanticipated, certainly.
Professor Sverdrup in particular became very interested in the role of upwelling as it affected these waters to the south of Point Conception.
And I think we had some of the first evidence on the existence of eddies in the area that these sort of features had not been identified before.
Who was joining you in Scripps between, let's say, 35 on?
You seem to have a whole series of people come in at Scripps about this time who go on.
Well, the biggest change has occurred, I feel, in about 1920.

which was just about the time I went there as a graduate student, and that Dr. Vaughn, who was the director, had been able to get some additional funds, and he had a really very imaginative sort of view of what ought to be done at that time, and he added two
faculty people, and Claude Zobel in microbiology, and Dennis Fox essentially in physiology and biochemistry.
This represented a major kind of shift in what was going on at Scripps.
In the physical area and the field work where

There were no sort of major additions to the faculty and staff, except during these years we had considerable support from people who were provided to the institution under the WPA, the Works Progress Administration.
One of the curious things is that the illustrations in my thesis were all drawn by
man whose background had been in architecture and was being supported on these federal funds, and all my graphs looked like architectural drawings.
But we had considerable staff support, technician support in those days from people who were assigned to scripts under the WPA program.
Gene LaFond was one person who worked very closely with this program, with and I.
And that was about it.
Things weren't quite as large as they are today.
Did you find much exchange among the faculty in that time?
In other words, were you able to come to, let's say, people like Martin Johnson and talk about your problems, many meetings, this sort of thing?
Not particularly.
As far as the kind of research work was concerned, everybody did their own particular job, but as I mentioned a few minutes ago, we did collect plankton samples on these cruises.
The phytoplankton were examined by Mr. Allen and
His associate, Easter Kopp, and Mark Johnson and his assistants and students did the work on the zooplankton.
So, yes, and the group was small enough that you did sort of see everybody frequently, and there was a good deal of exchange.
But it was not a, it didn't by any means involve all of the activities that
at Scripps or all the faculty.
When does Roger Revell get to Scripps?
Well, he arrived a month or two after I did in the summer of 1931 and came down to work on the sediment samples that had been collected on the cruise of the

non-magnetic vessel Carnegie during I think it was 1928-29 and he was to carry out this examination of the material under the direction of Dr. Vaughan but he also got interested in a number of things and we worked together on several
problems, one of them concerning the solubility of calcium carbonate and the precipitation of calcium carbonate in seawater.
And he also used to participate in some of these cruises that we made before the sardine investigations began in 1937.
In fact, he and I used to take the research vessel out most of the time when
acted as captain and deckhands.
We had only a one-man crew who was the engineer on the small vessel that was available.
It's been suggested to me recently that one of the problems with the modern oceanographers is they don't get their feet wet, so to speak.
They don't spend enough time on vessels.
Would you agree with that?
Well, yes and no.
I think the
character of the work at sea has changed as the vessels have become much larger and as the equipment has become much more complex, and that the vessel we had and the

the times I'm talking about prior to the sardine surveys was just called the scripts and she was a 55 foot trawler type vessel with a one man permanent crew and so the graduate students in general used to take out and run the ship essentially navigate as necessary do all of the sampling do all of the
sort of deckhand functions, as well as work on the samples after they were back in the laboratory.

Now it's more like, I have the feeling, as a graduate student goes out, it's more or less like going on an ocean liner, that they're just, in a sense, kind of a passenger on a big, relatively large vessel.
They have very little to do with the planning or with the
navigation, the operation of the vessels at sea, and usually don't know very much about what's going on except the specific sort of project they're engaged in.
So I think we've lost something in this process, and there's still some, I think, activities of the type that I'm
reminiscing about that are conducted in some nearshore work at various institutions.
But still, I find the students have a very sort of narrow concept of what goes on.
There we go.
About 15 seconds here.
What do you mean?
It pauses now?
Yeah, I've got a 15 second delay to make sure we don't overtake.

Now, it's also been suggested that with the advent of the computer in terms of collecting data and evaluating it and so forth, particularly concerning physical oceanography, that the physical oceanographer loses touch with what he's doing.
Would you agree with that?
Well, I certainly would, and that's one of the things that has bothered me a good deal in recent years is that as the capability to take

more data and to use a computer for various processing, routine processing, compilation, manipulation, compilation analysis, plotting, and so on, that the younger scientists don't have the kind of familiarity with the specific information that I think we had in years gone by.
I think I can say with some confidence that I used to know every observation that had ever been made in most of the Pacific Ocean.
And there weren't very many, but I knew every one and could evaluate it.
I knew whether it was good or bad.
I knew how it was related to other observations and so on.
And this kind of an intimacy is certainly being lost today,
students may not even see the set of original data in any form.
Times have changed, and I'm harking back to a condition that will probably never prevail again, but I think something has been lost here.
When you began to plan your voyages, let's say around 37 or 38, I'm interested in how you made your decisions, where to go, what to do.
Was it pretty well dictated by the fisheries itself, or were you pretty free to do what you wanted to do?
No, I would say that we were fairly free.
I'm talking only in terms of really one more or less specific

of operation, but within a rather general frame of reference, why we were allowed to plan our own program, and of course it was discussed with Alton Setty and Lionel Offord and others that were involved, but in general I think we decided what should be done and how it should be done and where to plan and so on.
And that there was a considerable freedom in choice here in what we did.
The other thing we were able to do at that time was to work out a fairly set of comprehensive programs as far as types of information gathered.
There's certainly a case always of trying to optimize what
we could do, because we had very limited resources in terms of money and people and equipment.
So we had to select fairly carefully what we felt we could do.
I have to remember that most of this was even before the days of the whole mechanical bathysemir graph, the VT.
In fact, we had the experience of working with

I think it was BT number 5, which was sent to us in the spring of 1941 by Woods Hole when nobody even knew whether the instrument would function properly and had no kind of experience with the kind of information you could get with a device of that kind.
When you were at Scripps in this period, was there much contact with international oceanography?
Did you have any international oceanographers come through?

Yes, we used to have quite a few visitors, at least relatively speaking, in that Professor Vaughn, who was the director from, actually I think it was from 1924 until 1936, had been relatively active in sort of international ocean activities.

matters, and had a number of friends and professional friends in foreign countries, Japan, Europe, and so on, and we were one of the relatively few places that anyone interested in the ocean would come to visit in the United States.
What I'm trying to say is there weren't very many places to visit, so we saw a good many of the
of the distinguished people from other areas.
And then when Professor Sverdrup came in, he had a very close bonds with many, many people in different fields and different countries, and this sort of continued in a way.
And I can remember, in particular, we had one or more visits from Helen Hansen, a Norwegian
oceanographer, and so we had reasonably good, I feel, in some ways, maybe better contacts than we have today.
Now, when you were involved in this in the 30s, was there sort of a sense of excitement about moving out towards a new frontier?
No, I don't think so.
It was all good fun, but we didn't see any great manifest destiny or anything for
We didn't think in terms of national ocean policy and so on.
We just thought there were interesting scientific problems to be solved.

And as I look back on it now, that period really before the war at Scripps, we were very much in sort of ivory tower, although as I've already indicated, we were beginning to move into what might be called applied oceanography as it was related to some of these fisheries problems.
But ordinarily, though, this is still primarily research for its own sake rather than sort of the applied research that comes out between 1941 and 1945?
Oh, yes.
The funding of the institution at that time, the Scripps Institution, was
basically all through the University of California, since the state funds reaching us through the university, except that in connection with the sardine investigations, the federal fisheries
agency did provide money to help operate the vessel, which was the E.W.
Scripps at that time.
This is after the Blue Fin.
We're getting in a number of omissions and so on in trying to trace the history of these things.
But we were all, we were not
We did not consider, as one would probably do now that we were dependent on federal funding to function.
We were essentially supported through the academic funds from the University of California.
There was also support from some of the members of the Scripps family, which was available at that time.
There has also been discussion that perhaps the nature of oceanography has changed for the worse and that they have lost sort of a jack-of-all-trades approach.
Would you agree with that?

Well, this is, I think, where personal prejudice has come in, and I would agree that I feel that one of the things that attracted me to the field originally was the fact that we were able to deal with a

what I consider is essentially a sort of a unified system, and where we could cross the disciplinary boundaries, which we did very freely at that time, between chemistry, physical aspects, biology, geology, without anybody raising an eyebrow.
And we did try and deal with the systems
well as we could as essentially unified systems.
And I think today it's become fragmented again by specialization, which is partly, I think, the result of the interest of the scientists who come into the field, but it's also being encouraged
in a sense, by the way in which the federal funding has become more and more specialized and fragmented.
And I don't consider this desirable at all.
Most of my efforts in recent years have been to try and bring the subject matter back together again as much as I can.
